Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Individuals' Assessments of Legitimate Authority

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Maintaining social order also depends on ordinary citizens perceiving that the exercise of legal authority is legitimate -- that is, deserving deference even in the absence of extrinsic (deterrence-based) compliance motivations. When authorities are viewed as legitimate, citizens have an enhanced intrinsic motivation to comply with the law and to cooperate with those who enforce it. This research tackles two key questions. What features of enforcement institutions bestow legitimacy on authorities? And what are the consequences of legitimacy for citizen behavior?

It employs both laboratory and lab-in-the-field experiments, the latter of which enhance policy relevance by focusing on subjects from low-income, mostly minority communities, whose experiences of law enforcement may differ from those of typical student subject pools. Assessing the causal antecedents of legitimate authority is a surprisingly tricky empirical problem. Given that citizens' compliance with the law may be motivated both by deterrence and by citizens' perceptions of legitimacy, how can legitimacy be measured in a way that is separate from citizens' anticipations of punishment? This work employs novel experiments designed to decouple the relationship between citizens' extrinsic (deterrence) and intrinsic (legitimacy-based) motivations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was a joint grant between NYU and Yale. The purpose of the research conducted under the auspices of the grant was to explore how the choices of leaders or other officials in positions of authority, and the institutional environments they occupy, affect the legitimacy with which they are perceived by ordinary subjects/citizens; and how, in turn these perceptions of legitimacy may affect cooperation or compliance. Because these behavioral and institutional factors affect not only the legitimacy of authorities but also the extrinsic motivations of ordinary people to comply, isolating legitimacy effects is a challenging task. Accordingly, the project consisted of the design, implementation, and evaluation of a sequence of behavioral experiments that allow the analyst to separate intrinsic motivations for cooperation and compliance from extrinsic ones.

Our behavioral experiments were conducted with three subject populations: a traditional laboratory population in a university setting;  a lab-in-the-field population drawn from participants in a non-carceral diversion program for at-risk young adults; and an online subject pool. The project was broadly successful and involved extensive opportunities for both graduate students and postdoctoral associates to participate in learning research techniques and conducting experimental research. Challenges occurred in implementing the lab-in-the-field portion of the research, owing to a change in staff in the non-profit with which the investigators were collaborating. These challenges account for the shift in emphasis to the online subject pool.

In terms of contributions to knowledge, the outcomes of this project have been several. First, our experiments will substantially clarify any subsequent efforts to disentangle intrinsic and extrinsic compliance motivations in a way previous research designs have not permitted. Most important in this regard has been our ability to exploit double-randomization to assess the impacts of authority choices on subject behavior holding constant all material motivations for compliance. Second, our results suggest that a leader’s efforts to secure more fair institutional environments, beyond the actual institutions that are put in place, increase citizen compliance in cooperative public goods provision. Third, while still ongoing, our analysis to date reveals no significant difference in the effects of random versus group-based costly monitoring on the behavior of subjects in the lab.
